author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Your writing is so good, I didn’t realize how much you’d just written until scrolling allllll the way back up to the top. 
I’ve got a few thoughts on this. 
1) always be cultivating a Yes/And atmosphere. 
2) Sales is all about excitement. As long as you’re excited about their work and your ideas, it’s gonna be easy and fun to work. 
3) Give it time. 9/10 when I wait to give me guys a note, they’ll address it themselves. But furthermore, when the afterglow wears off a bit, it’s easy to suggest things that will bring that feeling back. 
4) songs matter less than relationships. If you’re trying to serve the music at the expense of the relationship, you’re doing one of those things wrong.  

I could keep going but imma let you finish.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Man. Thank you for such a thoughtful answer. I'm going to really ponder this and work to internalize it. 

I'm very much a "give it to me straight" person. I really like to hear it direct and actively dislike when I perceive that people are sugarcoating things with me. But something I've realized lately is that I've curbed my own communication directed towards people in favor of a lighter touch and now I often have problems in creative scenarios being super direct with artists when I ought to be.

In short, I think I've overcorrected.

I think this is a result of having worked with so many artists over the years who wilt under the directness. Not everyone is like that, but I've had enough bad experiences communicating super directly that I've ended up hedging my style in favor of something far more soft.

author: ehutton21
content: Very much resonate with this. I feel like giving people things straight is important to having the best creative environment possible

author: ehutton21
content: You wanna give people the empowerment to be their own editor too, and I’ve found that asking questions that ask the artist to be their own judgement is a pretty valuable way to work with just about anyone. It makes sure the artist *owns* the lines they’re going to have to perform on the mic in studio and in an ideal world, for as many people as they can imagine.

author: BatMeckley
content: As a fundamental rule, I do my best to not bring up an issue with something unless I feel pretty strongly I’ve got the solution. At the very least, I make sure i can really specifically say WHY I’m not into an idea. Nothing I hate more than “that sucks, it just does”.

author: ehutton21

author: BatMeckley
content:
I had this corporate thing just recently where they commissioned me to do two songs, with the explicit understanding that I would do a series of revisions for them but due to time constraints they just got the two songs. So. They hated them lol (they asked if I could give them one more modern and then played me a song I’d worked on a decade ago). Wanted me to write a third, to which we responded “if you want to pay us for a third we’ll squeeze it in but otherwise just revisions on these two”. Meeting ended with an understanding we’d reconvene next day. 

Next day, we got the head of the department in. Very well spoken, very complimentary. Said they actually really liked the second song, could we just change the first half entirely. “You know what, we’ve had a lot of success together sure”. Couple seconds later… “could you also maybe totally rewrite the second half”. 

We politely told them to go fuck themselves.

content:
The world reinforces the idea that you should network and here's a million ways to expand your social media reach and all that.

Some of that is worthwhile advice, but most of it is there because you don't get clicks and you can't make money by telling people "just put in the time."

It's really that simple. It's difficult, because you're not gonna get positive feedback all the time and it takes a lot of time. But it's really simple.

If you wrote 1000 songs and then just put songs 1001-1010 out onto the internet, people will find you quickly because the songs will be great. I promise you.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I always think of Graham Linehan (now cancelled, but still) talking about creating The IT Crowd. He was trying to directly copy the format of Seinfeld as closely as he could, but inevitably, through the filter of his own life experiences, personality, culture etc etc he wound up with something completely removed and unique. 

Don’t worry about any of that while you’re creating. At worst, you might stand back when you’re done and realise you’ve wound up too close to something. So what? Change it, or start something new. But don’t let it strangle the baby before you’ve birthed it.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
We also are bad audiences for our music. It's impossible not to have huge blindspots about what of your work will be enjoyed by other people. So you really have to get that shit out of your head when creating.

Similarly, you cannot calculate or predict what will break you in your career. Yes, you can and should make strategic choices about what you work on. But it is so unpredictable that the best advice is "just make lots and lots more stuff."

author: oaklandmatt
content: Because when you make lots and lots more music, you're doing the thing that will maximally help you get really good at it and give maximal shots at people hearing your music.

author: austenballard
content:
We talk a lot about output but something I'm thinking about today is input

I pulled an all nighter cranking out beats and demos and by about 5am I was mentally running on empty but still very much awake (my heinous caffeine addiction is a matter for another time). Still had about 5 tracks to do, though

I took an hour to watch/listen to some concert videos - the watch part was important so I wouldn't be tempted to get distracted on my phone or something - and then got back to work. Got the other 5 done in a few hours.

All that is to say I think it's good to keep in mind how important it is to consume as much music as you put out, if not more.

Anyone have any good thoughts about this? I'm likening it to the notion of "information diet"

content: What I mean is environment more than social setting - there’s certain settings were Elliot smith will fit the bill far more than an EDM/rap/pop song. I guess the point I’m trying to make is to understand the context of where you want the song to be played and then don’t kill the vibe.

author: Josh

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. I think we're in that same camp.

It seems to imply a different kind of mental posture in listeners. Some people can hear a song and think "That's *me* that they're talking about here. That's so me." Others may listen to a song and think "That's the story of that person's life and what they've experienced."

author: Slow Hand
content:
The approach that Chilly is describing feels somewhat like crafting a Barnum statement; a broad proclamation about someone that anyone can see themselves in. Statements like:

> “You prefer a certain amount of change and variety and become dissatisfied when limited or restricted.”
> 
> "At times you have serious doubts as to whether you have made the right decision or done the right thing."
> 
> "At times you are extroverted, affable, sociable, while at other times you are introverted, wary, reserved."

While I find Barnum statements generally distasteful, I don't mean to make a value judgement here, because both approaches in songs can be great.

author: whaleintown
content: thank you , so I started by writing about myself and let's say I wrote 1 song/day for a month and I run out of story to tell. How would you approach this ? do you find other writers to write with ? or just keep writing same idea with different perspective ? or try different style ?

author: oaklandmatt
content:
You won't run out of story. And yes to all the ways you mentioned. Try them all. Combine them. Switch back and forth. Anything to get you to just keep writing.

The other thing to keep in mind is that you try your best not to worry if something is good or meaningful or important WHILE you're making it. Just make things because it feels interesting or fun, then decide at another time which ones you like the most.

author: Ross Fortune
content: * Never whine, preach, or vent - UNLESS you do it with humour, irony, and most importantly detail

author: Ross Fortune
content:
* Always make the character in the song look cool - the character is never a loser, and they’re never over 30. If there’s a loser in a song, it’s somebody else.

Think like you’re in a job interview: never share an experience that doesnt have a happy ending, end successfully or showcase you as a star.
You have to make every one of your artists a star.
The song is your opportunity to say the lines in real time that you only think of in your shower arguments later.

author: Zach Hughes
content: I think because I really love songs that I can see myself in and many of the songs that I connected with the most age 13-18 or so all had exceptions to those rules or just downright fly in the face of them. I guess I don't like the idea of rules or guidelines for song-writing when it feels prescriptive. I love music that expands my world not shrinks it and knowing there was a formula feels too narrow which I can more easily say in hindsight. I probably jammed to some songs that fit that particular bill too but I'd have to think more on it to remember 'em.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Haha yeah even if we never get to that level, I'd say something you can dump a million tokens worth of your personal context into will be quite good at finding custom solutions or where to find the solutions, even today

Tangentially on consuming the right things, I heard about the expression "Clarity Maxxing" the other day and it's an interesting counter-value to current productivity mindsets. Consume less information, but better information. Make sure to not optimize for just necessarily work, but work on the right things, and take time for your body/mind to recover. Seems so obvious, but at its core I think it's in conflict with a lot of current norms

author: Will Trotman
content:
So I’ve noticed that almost every writer I know (myself included) has said some version of “I need to be writing more,” with an implied “I feel anxious that I’m not doing enough.” I think sometimes that’s a reasonable way to feel, but writing (like all creative endeavors) is something you could technically always be doing, which I think makes it hard to know when you’re doing enough. I think this is specifically relevant to writers trying to pursue writing as a career.

Curious for thoughts on this. I definitely feel that kind of thing come and go, and have a hunch that it has to do with how “tuned in” I’m staying to look for songs and writing material in day to day life. I think that it’s challenging to identify as a writer but feel like you’ve gotten out of the swing of approaching life as a writer or artist.

Have many more thoughts on this but will leave it there for brevity’s sake. Question is basically what is “enough” and why is this such a common anxiety for writers.
